field_edited_text.value:
NAVIGATION CONSIDERATIONS 55

From the high point in the main span over the channel, the bridge and
approaches descend on 4 per cent grades in both directions, so that at the
north pierhead line a vertical clearance of 149 feet is provided, and at the
south pierhead line a vertical clearance of 91 feet is provided.

The main cantilever unit is comprised of a main river span 1224 feet long,
flanked on each side by anchor spans 668 feet long. The 2180 feet of spans
approaching the main cantilever unit from the south are two spans of 350
feet, two spans of 480 feet, and one span of 520 feet. The 2050 feet of
bridge approaching the main cantilever unit from the north is comprised of
one span of 520 feet, one of 480 feet and three of 350 feet. The main can-
tilever unit and side spans are shown in perspective on Plate 20.

The roadway is 46 feet wide between curbs, to accommodate four lanes
of traffic with two emergency footways, each 1 foot 6 inches wide. The
vertical curve over the main channel is 1534 feet long, and provides a
minimum sight distance of 875 feet. The alignment is straight, except for
a 3 degree and 30 minute curve immediately south of Boston Street.

The bridge has been designed for Standard H-20 loading, in accordance
with the Standard Specifications for Highway Bridges, adopted and pub-
lished by the American Highway Officials Association in 1935, except for
slight modifications, which are made necessary because the above named
specifications are intended to cover span lengths of 300 feet or less only.
The design of long span highway bridges involves the use of special design
provisions which have not been published as standard, but which have been
accepted by the engineering profession in connection with the long span
bridges recently built in this country.

The Standard H-20 loading referred to above is intended to provide for
trucks with maximum loads of 20 tons, placed anywhere on the roadway,
and in such number as to produce the maximum stress which might occur
in any member of the bridge or portion of the structure.

NAVIGATION CONSIDERATIONS

The main ship channels into Baltimore Harbor for the past 57 years,
since the year 1881, have been 600 feet wide. For 33 years, since 1905,
- these channels have been 35 feet deep. In 1929 other improvements to
the main ship channels, consisting principally of widening turns, etc., were
effected.

At a Hearing held on June 28, 1938, before the U. S. War Department
District Engineer of Baltimore, the Export and Import Bureau of the
